items.title: University spin-out Afynia secures $5M seed to commercialize its microRNA panel test for endometriosis
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Afynia Laboratories, a Canadian biotech startup from McMaster University, secured $5 million in seed funding for a blood test for endometriosis.
- Endometriosis affects nearly 200 million people globally, and diagnosis often takes years, delaying treatment.
- The test, named EndomiR, analyzes microRNA in blood to diagnose endometriosis more effectively than single biomarker tests.
- Afynia aims to simplify diagnosis, potentially reducing the average diagnosis time of upwards of seven years.
- They plan to launch the test in Canada this summer, with U.S. introduction expected next year.
- Funding was led by Bio-Rad Laboratories, with previous backing of $1.5 million in pre-seed funding from various investors.

items.title: Clicks brings its BlackBerry-style keyboard case to Android phones
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Clicks launches BlackBerry-style physical keyboard cases for Android devices.
- Available for Google Pixel, Motorola Razr+, and Samsung Galaxy S25, pre-orders start now.
- Pixel cases priced at $99; prices increase to $139 after March 21.
- Razr+ and Galaxy S25 cases also $99, with an increase to $139 post-deadline.
- Features include tactile feedback, backlit keys, USB-C charging, and a companion app for preferences.
- Cases tap into BlackBerry nostalgia; over 100,000 iPhone cases sold globally since 2024 launch.
- Some users have noted a learning curve for typing with the case, especially on iPhone.

items.title: YouTube is working to make ad slots less interruptive
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- YouTube announced changes to mid-roll ads effective May 12 to improve user experience and creator revenue.
- Fewer ads will be shown during interruptive moments; more ads will be placed at natural breaks in videos.
- Older videos will be updated to include ad slots at these natural breaks automatically.
- Creators can opt-out of automatic placements and keep some control over ad placements in YouTube Studio.
- YouTube is introducing a feature to help creators see if their ads are placed disruptively.
- A mix of auto and manual ads resulted in a 5% increase in revenue for some creators.
- The goal is to maintain viewer engagement by reducing interruptive ads.

items.title: FAA tests Starlink terminals as Musk claims Verizon tech is ‘not working’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- The Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is testing SpaceX Starlink satellite internet terminals in the national airspace system.
- Elon Musk criticized Verizon’s $2 billion system, claiming it is "not working" and enhances risk for air travelers.
- The FAA is specifically evaluating the reliability issues in Alaska, testing Starlink terminals at facilities in Atlantic City and Alaska.
- Transportation Secretary Sean Duffy mentioned that Musk would help to "upgrade" the air traffic control system.
- There are concerns about possible conflicts of interest as Musk's employees have close access to federal agencies regulating his businesses.

items.title: Sam Bankman-Fried’s first post from prison isn’t even good
items.summary:
- Sam Bankman-Fried made his first public post on X while serving a 25-year prison sentence.
- His post responded to an ultimatum from Elon Musk to federal employees.
- SBF expressed sympathy for government workers, commenting on his own unemployment experience.
- FTX's token, FTT, surged 30% after his post.
- The method of how he posted from prison remains unclear, as inmates typically cannot access social media.

items.title: IBM’s $6.4B HashiCorp acquisition cleared by UK
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- The U.K.’s antitrust authority has approved IBM’s acquisition of HashiCorp worth $6.4 billion.
- The decision follows a 10-month period of scrutiny since IBM announced the acquisition in April 2024.
- The Competition and Markets Authority (CMA) plans to publish its full rationale for the decision later.
- This acquisition aims to strengthen IBM’s position in the hybrid cloud space, following previous acquisitions of Red Hat and Apptio.
- The U.K. is attempting to project a pro-tech, pro-growth business stance amidst regulatory changes.
- The deal still awaits approval from the U.S. Federal Trade Commission (FTC).

items.title: DeepSeek reopens access to its API after three-week pause
items.summary:
- Chinese AI startup DeepSeek has reopened access to its API after a three-week service halt due to capacity issues.
- Starting February 25, 2025, customers can now top up credits for using DeepSeek's API.
- DeepSeek's R1 reasoning model has gained attention for matching OpenAI models, prompting OpenAI to consider open-sourcing more technology.
- Concurrently, Alibaba announced a preview of its reasoning AI model, QwQ-Max, aiming for open-source deployment.

items.title: Microsoft cancels some of its AI data center leases
items.summary:
- Microsoft is reducing its data center footprint by canceling leases with multiple data center providers, totaling a couple hundred megawatts of capacity, equivalent to about two data centers.
- The reasons for this decision are unclear but suggest a potential reset of expectations for future AI demand.
- In contrast, the industry is expanding, with announcements of significant funding for data centers from figures like Donald Trump and companies like OpenAI and SoftBank.

items.title: Apple’s Developer service comes to China’s WeChat
items.summary:
- Apple announced the integration of its Developer service into China’s WeChat app on February 25, 2025.
- This service includes news and announcements for developers, traditionally offered via Apple's website and Developer app.
- The move targets declining iPhone sales in China, which fell by 11.1% in the last quarter due to local competition from brands like Oppo and Huawei.
- Apple is working on introducing AI technologies from Tencent and ByteDance to enhance its product offerings in China.

items.title: DoorDash to pay delivery workers nearly $17M for using tips to cover wages
items.summary:
- DoorDash agreed to pay $16.75 million to settle a lawsuit from New York’s attorney general.
- The lawsuit accused DoorDash of using customer tips to cover the base pay of workers from May 2017 to September 2019.
- Approximately 63,000 New York delivery workers will benefit from the settlement.
- DoorDash stated that the allegations were related to a pay model retired in 2019, emphasizing commitment to fair earnings.

items.title: Mitico raises $4.3M seed round to capture CO2 using ‘prehistoric chemistry’
items.author: Tim De Chant
items.summary:
- Mitico has raised a $4.3 million seed round to develop a cost-effective carbon capture technology using potassium carbonate pebbles.
- The company's approach can capture over 95% of CO2 in exhaust streams, offering a potential cost of less than $85 per metric ton captured.
- Mitico aims to market its technology to industrial boiler users initially, and later expand to major CO2 emitters like natural gas power plants.

items.title: Redalpine, Founders Fund back Magdrive’s electric thruster business
items.author: Aria Alamalhodaei
items.summary:
- Magdrive, a UK startup, has developed an electric propulsion system for satellites that boasts higher thrust and lower mass compared to traditional systems.
- The company secured $10.5 million in funding led by Swiss fund Redalpine, aiming to manufacture commercial products and expand operations.
- Magdrive's technology utilizes solid metal propellant to generate high-energy plasma, enabling new mission capabilities in the space industry.
- The startup's systems, Rogue and Warlock, offer scalability and the potential to use in-space materials as fuel, differentiating them from competitors.
- Scheduled demonstrations of the Rogue thrusters are planned for June 2023; future systems include Warlock in 2026 and Super Magdrive in 2027.

items.title: Quantum Machines raises $170M, says it’s working with more than half of all quantum computing companies
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- Quantum Machines raised $170 million in a Series C funding round led by PSG Equity, with participation from Intel Capital and others.
- The company provides quantum control solutions and works with over half of the global quantum computing companies.
- Quantum Machines' technology helps reduce errors in quantum computing research, critical for building functional quantum computers.
- The startup experienced a significant uplift in valuation compared to previous fundraising rounds, originally pegged at $100 million.
- There are ongoing developments in the quantum computing sector, including innovations by Google and Microsoft, aiming for practical quantum applications in the next 5 to 10 years.

items.title: Adobe launches a Photoshop iPhone app
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Adobe introduces a mobile version of Photoshop for iPhone, available worldwide in the Apple App Store.
- The iPhone app includes both free and premium features with a subscription plan costing $7.99 monthly.
- Users can access core editing tools, such as layering, masking, and advanced AI tools like ‘Generative Fill’.

items.title: Serverless Cloud Platform Koyeb Integrates Tenstorrent’s AI Accelerators
items.author: Romain Dillet
items.summary:
- Koyeb now allows developers to utilize Tenstorrent’s AI accelerators shortly after the company raised nearly $700 million in funding.
- Tenstorrent’s AI processors are designed using the RISC-V architecture and offer an open-source neural network library, TT-NN, and programming model, TT-Metalium.
- Koyeb, founded by former Scaleway executives, provides a serverless cloud platform that automatically scales applications based on traffic demands.
- New instances include TT-N300S with 24GB GDDR6 memory and 466 FP8 TFLOPS, and TT-Loudbox with 96GB GDDR6 memory and 1,864 FP8 TFLOPS.
- Koyeb aims to be hardware-agnostic, positioning itself as an alternative to Nvidia's ecosystem.

items.title: Apple Watch shipments surge in India
items.author: Jagmeet Singh
items.summary:
- In 2024, smartwatch shipments in India dropped 30% year-on-year, with Apple experiencing a 141% increase in shipments.
- This surge follows a decline of 57% for Apple in 2023.
- Counterpoint analysts predict the trend of consumers moving to advanced smartwatches will continue into 2025.
- Apple holds about 2% of India’s smartwatch market, which shipped 35 million units last year.
- The Apple Watch led the premium smartwatch segment, comprising 50% of total sales priced above $230.

items.title: Perfect taps $23M to fix the flaws in recruitment with AI
items.summary:
- Startup Perfect, based in Israel, has raised $23 million in seed funding to improve recruitment processes using AI.
- The platform helps recruiters by saving them up to 25 hours of work per week and has grown its customer base from 20 to 200 businesses, including Fiverr and eToro.
- Perfect's founder, Eylon Etshtein, aims to replace outdated recruitment methods with proprietary data and automation to enhance recruitment efficiency.

items.title: Google launches a free AI coding assistant with very high usage caps
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Google introduced a free version of its AI coding assistant, **Gemini Code Assist for Individuals**, which allows natural language interaction for code editing.
- The tool offers **180,000 code completions** per month and **240 chat requests** daily, far exceeding the free GitHub Copilot's limits.
- It uses a **Gemini 2.0 AI model** with a **128,000-token context window** for handling complex codebases.
- The public preview for developers starts on the launch date (Tuesday).
- The service aims to attract new developers and potentially convert some to paid enterprise plans in the future.

items.title: EU’s top court ruling on Android Auto antitrust referral could put interoperability requests in the fast lane
items.author: Natasha Lomas
items.summary:
- The Court of Justice of the EU affirmed that refusal of interoperability by a dominant market player can constitute antitrust abuse.
- The ruling stems from Google’s past refusal to allow Enel X Italia's app access to Android Auto, deemed an abuse by Italy's competition authority.
- The court established criteria for justifying interoperability refusals, including technical impossibilities and potential security risks.
- Google expressed disappointment with the ruling, emphasizing its focus on user-centric development and the limited demand for the Enel-requested feature in Italy.

items.title: US employee screening giant DISA says hackers accessed data of more than 3M people
items.author: Carly Page
items.summary:
- DISA Global Solutions suffered a data breach affecting over 3.3 million individuals.
- The breach was reported in a filing to Maine's attorney general on February 25, 2025.
- The cyber incident was discovered on April 22, 2024, with a hacker accessing the network on February 9, 2024.
- Stolen data includes Social Security numbers, financial account information, and government-issued IDs.
- Over 360,000 Massachusetts residents were confirmed affected by the breach. 
- DISA indicated it lacked sufficient logs to determine the specifics of the data accessed by the hacker.

items.title: Thoma Bravo raises €1.8B for its first European fund
items.author: Paul Sawers
items.summary:
- Private equity firm Thoma Bravo closed its inaugural European fund at €1.8 billion ($1.9 billion).
- The fund aims to invest in mid-sized software companies across Europe.
- Thoma Bravo has previously invested around €14 billion in Europe since 2011.
- The closing of the fund reflects an opportunity to expand in a region where North American VC firms are retreating.
- The firm has launched its London office in 2023, marking its first hub outside the U.S.

items.title: Fyre Festival 2 is coming, and it already sounds bananas (and not in a good way)
items.summary:
- Billy McFarland announces Fyre Festival 2 scheduled for May 30 to June 2, 2025, in Isla Mujeres, Mexico.
- Ticket prices range from $1,400 to an excessive $1.1 million, despite no confirmed artists.
- McFarland’s legal status regarding international travel is unclear as he faces past convictions from the original Fyre Festival debacle in 2017.

items.title: Automattic-owned Beeper is releasing redesigned desktop and iOS apps
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- Automattic, owner of WordPress.com, acquired Beeper for $125 million in 2024.
- Beeper is launching redesigned beta apps for iOS and desktop based on its merger with Texts.com.
- The new apps are faster, consume less battery, and will eventually migrate users from the old app. 
- Data will be stored on-device in upcoming versions, featuring on-device encryption and multi-account support.
- Future Mac app updates will include iMessage support.
- Beeper was founded by Eric Migicovsky, who is now focused on reviving Pebble smartwatches.

items.title: 1,000 artists release ‘silent’ album to protest UK copyright sell-out to AI
items.author: Ingrid Lunden
items.summary:
- A group of 1,000 musicians released a "silent album" titled "Is This What We Want?" to protest U.K. copyright law changes.
- The album features recordings of empty studios and spaces, symbolizing the impact of proposed legislation allowing AI use of artists' content without payment.
- The album's track titles convey a message against potential music theft to benefit AI companies.
- Ed Newton-Rex, the project organizer, leads a campaign against AI training without licensing, with a petition signed by over 47,000 creatives.
- The album will be available on music platforms with proceeds going to charity Help Musicians, highlighting growing global concerns among artists.

items.title: UK’s internet watchdog toughens approach to deepfake porn
items.summary:
- Ofcom, U.K.'s internet safety regulator, issues new draft guidance to combat online threats against women and girls under the Online Safety Act.
- The guidance aims to tackle intimate image abuse, including deepfake porn, which is a priority for enforcement.
- Child safety campaigners express frustration over delays in implementing the Online Safety Act, which became law in September 2023.
- Initial enforcement of core OSA duties is set for next month, with full compliance guidance becoming enforceable by 2027.
- Ofcom emphasizes a 'safety by design' approach for online platforms to improve user safety and reduce risks associated with their services.
- The latest recommendations include using hash matching technology for detecting and removing abusive intimate imagery, especially deepfakes, amidst rising incidents reported in 2023.

items.title: Web Summit attendees aren’t buying Scale AI CEO’s push for America ‘to win the AI war’
items.summary:
- Scale AI CEO Alexandr Wang took out a full-page ad in The Washington Post urging Trump that ‘America must win the AI war.’
- During his Web Summit Qatar appearance, only two attendees agreed with Wang’s statement, while many disagreed.
- Wang views the competition in AI as a race between the U.S. and China, expressing concerns over China potentially surpassing Western military capabilities with AI.
- He advocates for U.S. models that support free speech compared to Chinese AI models influenced by government censorship.
- Scale AI recently announced a partnership with the Qatar government to develop AI-powered applications in various sectors.
- The discussion highlighted the mixed feelings among attendees regarding the U.S. being perceived as an AI superpower.

items.title: Anthropic reportedly ups its next funding round to $3.5B
items.summary:
- Anthropic is finalizing a $3.5 billion fundraising round, valuing the company at $61.5 billion.
- The company initially aimed to raise $2 billion but increased the target due to investor interest.
- Notable participants in the funding round include Lightspeed Venture Partners, General Catalyst, Bessemer Venture Partners, and MGX.
- If successful, this will bring Anthropic's total funding to approximately $18 billion.
- Despite a reported annualized revenue of $1.2 billion, Anthropic is still losing money and plans to use the funds for AI technology development.

items.title: Chegg Sues Google Over AI Search Summaries
items.summary:
- Chegg has sued Google, alleging that AI summaries in search results have negatively impacted its traffic and revenue.
- The lawsuit was filed in the U.S. District Court for the District of Columbia, accusing Google of unfair competition, monopoly maintenance, and unjust enrichment.
- Chegg seeks compensatory damages, relief, and an injunction against Google's allegedly unlawful practices.

items.title: Even Elon Musk forgets that X isn’t Twitter sometimes
items.summary:
- Elon Musk occasionally refers to X as Twitter, despite the rebranding.
- He recently posted about X adding features with fewer people compared to Twitter.
- Musk's message was in response to comments about government efficiency and federal employee productivity listings.
- This isn't the first instance of Musk using the name Twitter for X, indicating a potential habit.

items.title: Holmes and Balwani’s appeal falls flat as court upholds fraud convictions
items.author: Connie Loizos
items.summary:
- Elizabeth Holmes and Ramesh “Sunny” Balwani's appeals against their fraud convictions were denied by the Northern District Court of California.
- They were convicted in separate trials in 2022 for defrauding investors about Theranos’s blood-testing technology and began serving their sentences in 2023.
- The court upheld a joint restitution order of $452 million and dismissed arguments regarding improper testimony and violation of fair trial rights.

items.title: Apple exec Phil Schiller testifies that he raised concerns over App Store commissions on web-based sales
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- Phil Schiller testified he raised concerns about a 27% commission on external purchases.  
- He warned it could create an antagonistic relationship with app developers and raise compliance risks.  
- This commission reduction followed a court ruling that allowed developers to link to alternative payment methods.  
- Apple's default commission is 30%, but it dropped to 27% due to legal pressures.  
- Epic Games' CEO criticized Apple's compliance stating it was insufficient.  
- Schiller worried that Apple would become a collection agency affecting its relationship with developers.  
- Internal discussions revealed a lengthy debate at Apple regarding the commissions and potential impacts.  
- It was ultimately decided to charge a commission on external purchases despite Schiller's objections.  
- Documents indicated Apple considered how to implement external links without losing transactions.  
- New guidelines allow for a week to charge for external purchases after a link is clicked.

items.title: DOGE’s HR email is getting the ‘Bee Movie’ spam treatment
items.author: Amanda Silberling
items.summary:
- Elon Musk conducted a survey on X, asking if federal employees should email their weekly accomplishments to his team.
- Over 70% voted yes, leading to a request from the U.S. Office of Personnel Management for federal employees to list their achievements by Monday.
- Social media users are flooding the DOGE-operated HR email with spam, including the complete script of the 'Bee Movie', a tactic of online resistance against controversial emails.
- This follows a precedent of spamming government forms as a form of protest, including previous instances involving anti-trans forms.
- The OPM's HR email address recently faced scrutiny following a lawsuit regarding privacy violations related to the new email server setup.

items.title: A comprehensive list of 2024 and 2025 tech layoffs
items.summary: - In 2024, over 150,000 jobs were cut across 542 tech companies, according to Layoffs.fyi. - Major companies laying off employees include Tesla, Amazon, Google, and Microsoft. - The layoffs continue into 2025, with tracking to analyze the impact of these job cuts on innovation and employment stability. - Specific January 2025 layoffs include 6,003 employees, while December 2024 saw 2,268 laid off, and significant cuts occurred throughout each month of 2024.

items.title: Anthropic used Pokémon to benchmark its newest AI model
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Anthropic tested its latest AI model, Claude 3.7 Sonnet, using Pokémon Red as a benchmark.
- The model was equipped with memory and function calls to play the game continuously.
- Claude 3.7 successfully battled three Pokémon gym leaders, improving upon the previous Claude 3.0 version.
- The model performed 35,000 actions to reach the last gym leader, Surge.
- The testing method highlights gaming's role in AI benchmarking, similar to previous uses in titles like Street Fighter and Pictionary.

items.title: SpaceX says Starship self-destructed after propellant leaks caused fires and comms blackout
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- SpaceX reported the Starship explosion was due to propellant leaks leading to fires and communication loss.
- The company aims to conduct an eighth test flight soon, pending FAA investigation findings.
- Problems initiated two minutes post-launch, causing engine failures and triggering a destruction sequence.
- The explosion created a visual spectacle over Turks and Caicos and influenced FAA to divert flights.
- SpaceX has made adjustments to the fuel lines and engine systems to prevent future leaks.

items.title: SoundCloud partners with TicketMaster to let artists list events
items.author: Ivan Mehta
items.summary:
- SoundCloud announced a partnership with Ticketmaster to let artists list events on their profiles.
- Artists using SoundCloud's Pro plan can utilize Ticketmaster and Universe for event listings.
- SoundCloud will promote events through a concert discovery widget on its homepage.
- The platform takes a 1% cut from ticket sales made through Ticketmaster links.

items.title: Khosla Ventures seeks $3.5B in fresh capital
items.summary:
- Khosla Ventures aims to raise $3.5 billion across three funds, 17% larger than their previous 2023 total of $3 billion.
- Approximately half of the new funds will be allocated to its ninth core venture fund, with $1.1 billion for a growth fund and $650 million for a seed-stage fund.
- Founded in 2004 by Vinod Khosla, the firm has notable managing directors including Keith Rabois, who has a history with investments in companies like DoorDash and Affirm.

items.title: Google Drive users can now access and search transcripts for videos
items.author: Aisha Malik
items.summary:
- Google Drive has launched a new feature allowing users to view and search transcripts for their videos.
- This feature eliminates the need for third-party transcription services, as transcripts will appear in a sidebar next to the video player.
- Users can access transcripts by opening a video with captions and selecting the “Transcript” option in video settings.
- The feature is rolling out over the coming weeks to all Google Workspace customers and users with personal Google accounts.

items.title: Anthropic launches a new AI model that ‘thinks’ as long as you want
items.author: Maxwell Zeff
items.summary:
- Anthropic introduces Claude 3.7 Sonnet, the first ‘hybrid AI reasoning model’ that offers real-time and thorough answers.
- The model allows users to choose the duration of reasoning time, enhancing user experience by simplifying options.
- Claude 3.7 Sonnet will be available to all users on a premium plan, costing $3 per million input tokens and $15 per million output tokens.
- In tests, Claude 3.7 Sonnet achieved accuracy rates of 62.3% on SWE-Bench and 81.2% on TAU-Bench, outperforming OpenAI models.
- Claude’s new reasoning features are expected to reduce unnecessary rejections by 45% compared to its predecessor, Claude 3.5 Sonnet.
- Alongside this model, Anthropic is also launching Claude Code, a tool for developers to interact with AI directly from their terminal.

items.title: Grok 3 appears to be driving Grok usage to new heights
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- Elon Musk’s AI company, xAI, released [Grok 3](https://techcrunch.com/2025/02/17/elon-musks-ai-company-xai-releases-its-latest-flagship-ai-grok-3/), its flagship AI model, last week.
- Grok 3 led to a more than 10x increase in worldwide and U.S. mobile app downloads compared to the previous week, with daily active users in the U.S. soaring over 260%.
- The web app's U.S. daily visits rose from around 189,000 to over 900,000, globally growing from 627,000 to 4.5 million.
- Grok 3’s release coincided with the app expanding into several new markets, possibly aiding its growth.
- Recent controversies included Grok 3 briefly censoring mentions of Donald Trump and Musk, attributed to a rogue employee, and it making problematic statements about them which were quickly patched.

items.title: DeepSeek: Everything you need to know about the AI chatbot app
The SEC will not sue Robinhood over crypto
items.summary:
- Robinhood announced that the SEC has closed its investigation into its crypto unit and will not pursue action.
- This comes after Coinbase also reported that the SEC dropped its lawsuit against them.
- The SEC had investigated multiple crypto exchanges regarding how they handled staking assets, which it viewed as unregistered securities.
- Robinhood chose to limit its involvement in certain crypto assets to avoid triggering SEC scrutiny.
- The crypto industry is now seeking to establish regulations, especially under a more crypto-friendly administration.

items.title: Perplexity teases a web browser called Comet
items.author: Kyle Wiggers
items.summary:
- AI-powered search engine Perplexity announces it is building a web browser named Comet.
- A signup list has been launched, but the browser is not yet available.
- Perplexity aims to "reinvent the browser" alongside its search engine innovations.
- The browser will compete in a crowded market with existing browsers like Chrome and upcoming AI-powered options like Dia.
- Perplexity has recently expanded its product portfolio, including a deep research product and an AI assistant for Android.
- Founded in 2022, Perplexity has raised over $500 million and has a valuation of $9 billion, with over 100 million weekly search queries.
- The company faces legal challenges regarding content usage from publishers like News Corp and The New York Times.

items.title: Three years on, Europe looks to Ukraine for the future of defense tech
items.summary:
- Today marks three years since Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, highlighting Ukrainian innovation in defense technology amidst the conflict.
- Ukraine established the BRAVE1 defense tech initiative and hosted tech conferences like IT Arena.
- Ukraine has become a leader in AI-enabled drone technology, attracting Western investment to enhance European defense.
- A report by Lakestar warns that Europe is underprepared for potential threats, citing a reduction in defense spending by 30% since the 1990s.
- In 2024, venture capital investment in European defense technology reached over a billion dollars, with significant investments focused in Germany, the UK, and France.
- New specialized defense funds and startups in Ukraine are emerging, with various innovative solutions being developed for defense and dual-use technology.

items.title: TikTok (with Douyin) becomes first app to reach $6B in annual consumer spending
items.author: Sarah Perez
items.summary:
- In 2024, TikTok and its Chinese counterpart Douyin reached $6 billion in annual in-app purchase revenue, becoming the first non-game app to do so.
- TikTok generated a record $1.9 billion in IAP revenue in Q4 2024, surpassing all other non-game apps except for YouTube and Google One.
- TikTok's IAP revenue represents a significant increase from $4.4 billion in 2023.
- Despite high revenue, TikTok was ranked No. 2 in downloads for Q4 2024, behind Instagram.
- Douyin, tailored for the Chinese audience, offers stricter content controls and emphasizes e-commerce more than TikTok.
- TikTok's popularity illustrates its importance in the creator economy, where users can purchase virtual gifts for creators.

items.title: Australia bans government use of Kaspersky software due to ‘unacceptable security risk’
items.summary:
- Australia bans the use of Kaspersky software by government officials due to security risks.
- Directive issued by the Department of Home Affairs prohibits installation of Kaspersky products by April 1.
- Australia joins the Five Eyes intelligence pact members in restricting Kaspersky, including the U.S., U.K., and Canada.

items.title: Researchers accuse North Korea of $1.4 billion Bybit crypto heist
items.author: Lorenzo Franceschi-Bicchierai
items.summary:
- Hackers stole approximately $1.4 billion in Ethereum from crypto exchange Bybit, marking it as the largest crypto heist ever.
- Blockchain monitoring firms and investigator ZachXBT attribute the hack to North Korea's Lazarus Group.
- Elliptic and TRM Labs confirmed North Korea's involvement based on the analysis of stolen funds' laundering patterns.

items.title: The startup battle begins now: TechCrunch Startup Battlefield 200 applications are open
items.summary:
- Applications for the TechCrunch Startup Battlefield 200 are now open.
- The event will take place from October 27-29 at Moscone West in San Francisco.
- Competitors have the chance to win a $100,000 equity-free prize and gain exposure to investors.
- Last year's competition saw thousands of startups apply, indicating fierce competition ahead.
- Early application is encouraged for better chances of consideration.
- Notable alumni include Trello, Mint, and Discord, with over 1,500 alumni in total.
- Target participants include early-stage startups with an MVP and transformative vision.

items.title: As Meta gets rid of fact-checkers, misinformation is going viral
items.summary:
- Meta is ending its third-party fact-checking programs in the U.S. while reintroducing a bonus program for viral content creators.
- The change may lead to increased misinformation as content moderation is being deprioritized.
- Current policies preventing monetization of false posts are being lifted.
- Meta's fact-checking transition will occur in March 2025, but false claims are already spreading.
- Example of misinformation includes a fake claim about ICE paying $750 for tips on undocumented immigrants.

items.title: Flexport releases onslaught of AI tools in a move inspired by ‘Founder Mode’
items.author: Sean O’Kane
items.summary:
- Flexport is launching a suite of over 20 new AI-powered products, marking the start of semi-annual announcements.
- The new approach is inspired by Airbnb’s product announcement strategy, as advised by Airbnb’s CEO, Brian Chesky.
- Key products include Flexport Intelligence for natural language queries on shipments and Control Tower for real-time visibility in logistics.
- AI tools are designed to enhance customer relations rather than replace staff; Flexport believes it will lead to job growth.
- Petersen emphasizes cautious integration of AI, particularly with voice agents for logistics communication, ensuring high quality in customer interactions.
- The next product release is expected in late summer 2025.
